description: Borrowed from French curette, from curer (“to clean out, scrape out”).

entries.meaning: (medicine, dentistry) A hand-held surgical instrument, often with a scoop or hook at its tip, used for cleaning or debriding biological tissue.
examples: Curettes are used for the subgingival removal of dental deposits and for root planing. They can also be used supragingivally. The working tip of a curette is more slender than that of a scaler.

verbs.description: curette (third-person singular simple present curettes, present participle curetting, simple past and past participle curetted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, medicine) To scrape with a curette.
